fields.description:
When logged into an old EC2 account without VPC, VPC is still reported under account attributes (supported-platforms). That is currently our only test for VPC on an account. On this old EC2 account, there are no VPCs defined (not even 'default') and so operations like creating a rule with SCTP protocol fail. We should do like the AWS console and disable VPC features if there are no VPCs for the account (as well as the account attribute check).

I marked this critical because we will allow some operations that actually fail when executed, but not a blocker because user just could avoid those things.

comments.body: For a security group we should check if the group being edited is a VPC group, as you can have both VPC and non-VPC groups if both classic and VPC are available.

[~sjones], we do check and allow editing of inbound and outbound rules if it is a VPC group. Additionally, when creating a group in VPC, we allow setting the VPC network. I've attached a shot of 2 default groups on the landing page, one VPC, one classic.

[~dkavanagh], sounds good. Note that there will not necessarily be a "Default VPC" even if there are some VPCs in the account, so when creating a security group without specifying a VPC we'd need to be careful about what rules were added as VPC specific rules may not be appropriate.
I've come up with a simple fix for this, which is low risk. Worth noting this problem would only affect earlier AWS accounts that lack even a default VPC.

resources affected:
elbs
instances
elastic ip
launch configs
scaling groups
security groups

So, I would suggest create and display of those things would be like "classic" networking with this fix on those specific accounts.

Seems critical to fix this in 4.2 if we can’t create the resources David listed above in non-VPC AWS accounts.  Note that PR 1619 is isolated to AWS login code, so regression checks would only need to be performed on the AWS side of the console.

per arch call, newer regions *may* have a default VPC for an account and capabilities could be different, so we need to move the capabilities/vpc check to region switch, not just login. (but, certainly both).
PR has been updated and properly detects VPC-ness per-region. My account has 1 VPC in the Sao Paolo region, but not in most others.

[~dkavanagh]: My US East region doesn't have any VPCs, yet the "Allocate Elastic IP Addresses" dialog displays "Standard" and "VPC" as scope options (--screenshot attached).  The issue also seems to be on the master branch, so if it isn't a simple fix perhaps we need a new ticket for that?
Yes, I'd say if the code isn't relying on the BaseView.is_vpc_supported() call, then it needs it's own ticket.
[~dkavanagh]: Understood, I've opened GUI-2138 to address that.
[~dkavanagh], [~kgill]: I've checked all my AWS regions and all have VPC so I currently can't test this.  Is there another account I can use to test this?
I've heard that w/ the company account, a VPC could be deleted from some region to test this. Otherwise, we can screen-share and use my personal account.

Verified on console installed on shared setup #1, using my AWS account on a non-VPC region (us-east-1)...
https://console-lb-000840838253.lb.c-04.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com

Without the fix in GUI-1978, there are VPC-related anomalies (e.g. GUI-2140) in non-VPC regions.
